text: When God began to create the heavens and the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: the earth was complete chaos, and darkness covered the face of the deep, while a wind from God swept over the face of the waters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let there be light,” and there was light.
speaker: God

text: And God saw that the light was good, and God separated the light from the darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: God called the light Day, and the darkness he called Night. And there was evening and there was morning, the first day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God said, “Let there be a dome in the midst of the waters, and let it separate the waters from the waters.”
speaker: God

text: So God made the dome and separated the waters that were under the dome from the waters that were above the dome. And it was so.
speaker: Narrator

text: God called the dome Sky. And there was evening and there was morning, the second day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God said, “Let the waters under the sky be gathered together into one place, and let the dry land appear.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: God called the dry land Earth, and the waters that were gathered together he called Seas. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the earth put forth vegetation: plants yielding seed and fruit trees of every kind on earth that bear fruit with the seed in it.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: The earth brought forth vegetation: plants yielding seed of every kind and trees of every kind bearing fruit with the seed in it. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there was evening and there was morning, the third day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God said, “Let there be lights in the dome of the sky to separate the day from the night, and let them be for signs and for seasons and for days and years,
speaker: God

text: and let them be lights in the dome of the sky to give light upon the earth.” And it was so.
speaker: Narrator

text: God made the two great lights—the greater light to rule the day and the lesser light to rule the night—and the stars.
speaker: Narrator

text: God set them in the dome of the sky to give light upon the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: to rule over the day and over the night, and to separate the light from the darkness. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there was evening and there was morning, the fourth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God said, “Let the waters bring forth swarms of living creatures, and let birds fly above the earth across the dome of the sky.”
speaker: God

text: So God created the great sea monsters and every living creature that moves, of every kind, with which the waters swarm and every winged bird of every kind. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: God blessed them, saying, “Be fruitful and multiply and fill the waters in the seas, and let birds multiply on the earth.”
speaker: God

text: And there was evening and there was morning, the fifth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God said, “Let the earth bring forth living creatures of every kind: cattle and creeping things and wild animals of the earth of every kind.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: God made the wild animals of the earth of every kind and the cattle of every kind and everything that creeps upon the ground of every kind. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let us make humans in our image, according to our likeness, and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea and over the birds of the air and over the cattle and over all the wild animals of the earth and over every creeping thing that creeps upon the earth.”
speaker: God
Narrator

text: God blessed them, and God said to them, “Be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth and subdue it and have dominion over the fish of the sea and over the birds of the air and over every living thing that moves upon the earth.”
speaker: God

text: God said, “See, I have given you every plant yielding seed that is upon the face of all the earth and every tree with seed in its fruit; you shall have them for food.
speaker: God

text: And to every beast of the earth and to every bird of the air and to everything that creeps on the earth, everything that has the breath of life, I have given every green plant for food.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: God saw everything that he had made, and indeed, it was very good. And there was evening and there was morning, the sixth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus the heavens and the earth were finished and all their multitude.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the sixth day God finished the work that he had done, and he rested on the seventh day from all the work that he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: So God blessed the seventh day and hallowed it, because on it God rested from all the work that he had done in creation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the generations of the heavens and the earth when they were created.
In the day that the Lord God made the earth and the heavens,
speaker: Narrator

text: when no plant of the field was yet in the earth and no vegetation of the field had yet sprung up—for the Lord God had not caused it to rain upon the earth, and there was no one to till the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text: but a stream would rise from the earth and water the whole face of the ground—
speaker: Narrator

text: then the Lord God formed man from the dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and the man became a living being.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord God planted a garden in Eden, in the east, and there he put the man whom he had formed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of the ground the Lord God made to grow every tree that is pleasant to the sight and good for food, the tree of life also in the midst of the garden, and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: A river flows out of Eden to water the garden, and from there it divides and becomes four branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the first is Pishon; it is the one that flows around the whole land of Havilah, where there is gold,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the gold of that land is good; bdellium and onyx stone are there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the second river is Gihon; it is the one that flows around the whole land of Cush.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the third river is Tigris, which flows east of Assyria. And the fourth river is the Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God took the man and put him in the garden of Eden to till it and keep it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord God commanded the man, “You may freely eat of every tree of the garden,
speaker: God

text: but of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil you shall not eat, for in the day that you eat of it you shall die.”
speaker: God

text: Then the Lord God said, “It is not good that the man should be alone; I will make him a helper as his partner.”
speaker: God

text: So out of the ground the Lord God formed every animal of the field and every bird of the air and brought them to the man to see what he would call them, and whatever the man called every living creature, that was its name.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man gave names to all cattle and to the birds of the air and to every animal of the field, but for the man there was not found a helper as his partner.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord God caused a deep sleep to fall upon the man, and he slept; then he took one of his ribs and closed up its place with flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the rib that the Lord God had taken from the man he made into a woman and brought her to the man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the man said,
“This at last is bone of my bones
    and flesh of my flesh;
this one shall be called Woman,
    for out of Man this one was taken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore a man leaves his father and his mother and clings to his wife, and they become one flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the man and his wife were both naked and were not ashamed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the serpent was more crafty than any other wild animal that the Lord God had made. He said to the woman, “Did God say, ‘You shall not eat from any tree in the garden’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman said to the serpent, “We may eat of the fruit of the trees in the garden,
speaker: Narrator

text: but God said, ‘You shall not eat of the fruit of the tree that is in the middle of the garden, nor shall you touch it, or you shall die.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the serpent said to the woman, “You will not die,
speaker: Narrator

text: for God knows that when you eat of it your eyes will be opened, and you will be like God, knowing good and evil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So when the woman saw that the tree was good for food and that it was a delight to the eyes and that the tree was to be desired to make one wise, she took of its fruit and ate, and she also gave some to her husband, who was with her, and he ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the eyes of both were opened, and they knew that they were naked, and they sewed fig leaves together and made loincloths for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: They heard the sound of the Lord God walking in the garden at the time of the evening breeze, and the man and his wife hid themselves from the presence of the Lord God among the trees of the garden.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord God called to the man and said to him, “Where are you?”
speaker: God

text: He said, “I heard the sound of you in the garden, and I was afraid, because I was naked, and I hid myself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Who told you that you were naked? Have you eaten from the tree of which I commanded you not to eat?”
speaker: God

text: The man said, “The woman whom you gave to be with me, she gave me fruit from the tree, and I ate.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God said to the woman, “What is this that you have done?” The woman said, “The serpent tricked me, and I ate.”
speaker: God

text:
The Lord God said to the serpent,
“Because you have done this,
    cursed are you among all animals
    and among all wild creatures;
upon your belly you shall go,
    and dust you shall eat
    all the days of your life.
speaker: God

text:
I will put enmity between you and the woman
    and between your offspring and hers;
he will strike your head,
    and you will strike his heel.”
speaker: God

text:
To the woman he said,
“I will make your pangs in childbirth exceedingly great;
    in pain you shall bring forth children,
yet your desire shall be for your husband,
    and he shall rule over you.”
speaker: God

text:
And to the man he said,
“Because you have listened to the voice of your wife
    and have eaten of the tree
about which I commanded you,
    ‘You shall not eat of it,’
cursed is the ground because of you;
    in toil you shall eat of it all the days of your life;
speaker: God

text:
thorns and thistles it shall bring forth for you;
    and you shall eat the plants of the field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the sweat of your face
    you shall eat bread
until you return to the ground,
    for out of it you were taken;
you are dust,
    and to dust you shall return.”
speaker: God

text: The man named his wife Eve because she was the mother of all living.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord God made garments of skins for the man and for his wife and clothed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God said, “See, the humans have become like one of us, knowing good and evil, and now they might reach out their hands and take also from the tree of life and eat and live forever”—
speaker: God

text: therefore the Lord God sent them forth from the garden of Eden, to till the ground from which they were taken.
speaker: God

text: He drove out the humans, and at the east of the garden of Eden he placed the cherubim and a sword flaming and turning to guard the way to the tree of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the man knew his wife Eve, and she conceived and bore Cain, saying, “I have produced a man with the help of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Next she bore his brother Abel. Now Abel was a keeper of sheep, and Cain a tiller of the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the course of time Cain brought to the Lord an offering of the fruit of the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Abel for his part brought of the firstlings of his flock, their fat portions. And the Lord had regard for Abel and his offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: but for Cain and his offering he had no regard. So Cain was very angry, and his countenance fell.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Cain, “Why are you angry, and why has your countenance fallen?
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do well, will you not be accepted? And if you do not do well, sin is lurking at the door; its desire is for you, but you must master it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Cain said to his brother Abel, “Let us go out to the field.” And when they were in the field, Cain rose up against his brother Abel and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Cain, “Where is your brother Abel?” He said, “I do not know; am I my brother’s keeper?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “What have you done? Listen, your brother’s blood is crying out to me from the ground!
speaker: Narrator

text: And now you are cursed from the ground, which has opened its mouth to receive your brother’s blood from your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you till the ground, it will no longer yield to you its strength; you will be a fugitive and a wanderer on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Cain said to the Lord, “My punishment is greater than I can bear!
speaker: Narrator

text: Today you have driven me away from the soil, and I shall be hidden from your face; I shall be a fugitive and a wanderer on the earth, and anyone who meets me may kill me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to him, “Not so! Whoever kills Cain will suffer a sevenfold vengeance.” And the Lord put a mark on Cain, so that no one who came upon him would kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Cain went away from the presence of the Lord and settled in the land of Nod, east of Eden.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cain knew his wife, and she conceived and bore Enoch, and he built a city and named it Enoch after his son Enoch.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Enoch was born Irad, and Irad was the father of Mehujael, and Mehujael the father of Methushael, and Methushael the father of Lamech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech took two wives; the name of the one was Adah, and the name of the other Zillah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adah bore Jabal; he was the ancestor of those who live in tents and have livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: His brother’s name was Jubal; he was the ancestor of all those who play the lyre and pipe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zillah bore Tubal-cain, who made all kinds of bronze and iron tools. The sister of Tubal-cain was Naamah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lamech said to his wives:
“Adah and Zillah, hear my voice;
    you wives of Lamech, listen to what I say:
I have killed a man for wounding me,
    a young man for striking me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If Cain is avenged sevenfold,
    truly Lamech seventy-sevenfold.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Adam knew his wife again, and she bore a son and named him Seth, for she said, “God has appointed for me another child instead of Abel, because Cain killed him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: To Seth also a son was born, and he named him Enosh. At that time people began to invoke the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the list of the descendants of Adam. When God created humans, he made them in the likeness of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Male and female he created them, and he blessed them and called them humans when they were created.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Adam had lived one hundred thirty years, he became the father of a son in his likeness, according to his image, and named him Seth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The days of Adam after he became the father of Seth were eight hundred years, and he had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus all the days that Adam lived were nine hundred thirty years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Seth had lived one hundred five years, he became the father of Enosh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seth lived after the birth of Enosh eight hundred seven years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus all the days of Seth were nine hundred twelve years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Enosh had lived ninety years, he became the father of Kenan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enosh lived after the birth of Kenan eight hundred fifteen years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus all the days of Enosh were nine hundred five years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Kenan had lived seventy years, he became the father of Mahalalel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenan lived after the birth of Mahalalel eight hundred and forty years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus all the days of Kenan were nine hundred and ten years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Mahalalel had lived sixty-five years, he became the father of Jared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mahalalel lived after the birth of Jared eight hundred thirty years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus all the days of Mahalalel were eight hundred ninety-five years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jared had lived one hundred sixty-two years he became the father of Enoch.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jared lived after the birth of Enoch eight hundred years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus all the days of Jared were nine hundred sixty-two years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Enoch had lived sixty-five years, he became the father of Methuselah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch walked with God after the birth of Methuselah three hundred years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus all the days of Enoch were three hundred sixty-five years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch walked with God; then he was no more, because God took him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Methuselah had lived one hundred eighty-seven years, he became the father of Lamech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Methuselah lived after the birth of Lamech seven hundred eighty-two years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus all the days of Methuselah were nine hundred sixty-nine years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Lamech had lived one hundred eighty-two years, he became the father of a son;
speaker: Narrator

text: he named him Noah, saying, “Out of the ground that the Lord has cursed this one shall bring us relief from our work and from the toil of our hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech lived after the birth of Noah five hundred ninety-five years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus all the days of Lamech were seven hundred seventy-seven years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Noah was five hundred years old, Noah became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When people began to multiply on the face of the ground, and daughters were born to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: the sons of God saw that they were fair, and they took wives for themselves of all that they chose.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “My spirit shall not abide in mortals forever, for they are flesh; their days shall be one hundred twenty years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Nephilim were on the earth in those days—and also afterward—when the sons of God went in to the daughters of humans, who bore children to them. These were the heroes that were of old, warriors of renown.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord saw that the wickedness of humans was great in the earth and that every inclination of the thoughts of their hearts was only evil continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord was sorry that he had made humans on the earth, and it grieved him to his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said, “I will blot out from the earth the humans I have created—people together with animals and creeping things and birds of the air—for I am sorry that I have made them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Noah found favor in the sight of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the descendants of Noah. Noah was a righteous man, blameless in his generation; Noah walked with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Noah had three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the earth was corrupt in God’s sight, and the earth was filled with violence.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God saw that the earth was corrupt, for all flesh had corrupted its ways upon the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God said to Noah, “I have determined to make an end of all flesh, for the earth is filled with violence because of them; now I am going to destroy them along with the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make yourself an ark of cypress wood; make rooms in the ark, and cover it inside and out with pitch.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how you are to make it: the length of the ark three hundred cubits, its width fifty cubits, and its height thirty cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make a roof for the ark, and finish it to a cubit above, and put the door of the ark in its side; make it with lower, second, and third decks.
speaker: Narrator

text: For my part, I am going to bring a flood of waters on the earth, to destroy from under heaven all flesh in which is the breath of life; everything that is on the earth shall die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will establish my covenant with you, and you shall come into the ark, you, your sons, your wife, and your sons’ wives with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And of every living thing, of all flesh, you shall bring two of every kind into the ark, to keep them alive with you; they shall be male and female.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of the birds according to their kinds and of the animals according to their kinds, of every creeping thing of the ground according to its kind, two of every kind shall come in to you, to keep them alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also take with you every kind of food that is eaten, and store it up, and it shall serve as food for you and for them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah did this; he did all that God commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Noah, “Go into the ark, you and all your household, for I have seen that you alone are righteous before me in this generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take with you seven pairs of all clean animals, the male and its mate; and a pair of the animals that are not clean, the male and its mate;
speaker: Narrator

text: and seven pairs of the birds of the air also, male and female, to keep their kind alive on the face of all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in seven days I will send rain on the earth for forty days and forty nights, and every living thing that I have made I will blot out from the face of the ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Noah did all that the Lord had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah was six hundred years old when the flood of waters came on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Noah with his sons and his wife and his sons’ wives went into the ark to escape the waters of the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of clean animals and of animals that are not clean and of birds and of everything that creeps on the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text: two and two, male and female, went into the ark with Noah, as God had commanded Noah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after seven days the waters of the flood came on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the six hundredth year of Noah’s life, in the second month, on the seventeenth day of the month, on that day all the fountains of the great deep burst forth, and the windows of the heavens were opened.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rain fell on the earth forty days and forty nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the very same day Noah with his sons, Shem and Ham and Japheth, and Noah’s wife and the three wives of his sons entered the ark,
speaker: Narrator

text: they and every wild animal of every kind and all domestic animals of every kind and every creeping thing that creeps on the earth and every bird of every kind.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went into the ark with Noah, two and two of all flesh in which there was the breath of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: And those that entered, male and female of all flesh, went in as God had commanded him, and the Lord shut him in.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flood continued forty days on the earth, and the waters increased and bore up the ark, and it rose high above the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The waters swelled and increased greatly on the earth, and the ark floated on the face of the waters.
speaker: Narrator

text: The waters swelled so mightily on the earth that all the high mountains under the whole heaven were covered;
speaker: Narrator

text: the waters swelled above the mountains, covering them fifteen cubits deep.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all flesh died that moved on the earth, birds, domestic animals, wild animals, all swarming creatures that swarm on the earth, and all human beings;
speaker: Narrator

text: everything on dry land in whose nostrils was the breath of life died.
speaker: Narrator

text: He blotted out every living thing that was on the face of the ground, human beings and animals and creeping things and birds of the air; they were blotted out from the earth. Only Noah was left and those with him in the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the waters swelled on the earth for one hundred fifty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God remembered Noah and all the wild animals and all the domestic animals that were with him in the ark. And God made a wind blow over the earth, and the waters subsided;
speaker: Narrator

text: the fountains of the deep and the windows of the heavens were closed, the rain from the heavens was restrained,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the waters gradually receded from the earth. At the end of one hundred fifty days the waters had abated,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the seventh month, on the seventeenth day of the month, the ark came to rest on the mountains of Ararat.
speaker: Narrator

text: The waters continued to abate until the tenth month; in the tenth month, on the first day of the month, the tops of the mountains appeared.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of forty days Noah opened the window of the ark that he had made
speaker: Narrator

text: and sent out the raven, and it went to and fro until the waters were dried up from the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he sent out the dove from him to see if the waters had subsided from the face of the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the dove found no place to set its foot, and it returned to him to the ark, for the waters were still on the face of the whole earth. So he put out his hand and took it and brought it into the ark with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He waited another seven days, and again he sent out the dove from the ark,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the dove came back to him in the evening, and there in its beak was a freshly plucked olive leaf; so Noah knew that the waters had subsided from the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he waited another seven days and sent out the dove, and it did not return to him any more.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the six hundred first year, in the first month, on the first day of the month, the waters were dried up from the earth, and Noah removed the covering of the ark and looked and saw that the face of the ground was drying.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the earth was dry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Noah,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go out of the ark, you and your wife and your sons and your sons’ wives with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring out with you every living thing that is with you of all flesh—birds and animals and every creeping thing that creeps on the earth—so that they may abound on the earth and be fruitful and multiply on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Noah went out with his sons and his wife and his sons’ wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: And every animal, every creeping thing, and every bird, everything that moves on the earth, went out of the ark by families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Noah built an altar to the Lord and took of every clean animal and of every clean bird and offered burnt offerings on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the Lord smelled the pleasing odor, the Lord said in his heart, “I will never again curse the ground because of humans, for the inclination of the human heart is evil from youth; nor will I ever again destroy every living creature as I have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As long as the earth endures,
    seedtime and harvest, cold and heat,
summer and winter, day and night
    shall not cease.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God blessed Noah and his sons and said to them, “Be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fear and dread of you shall rest on every animal of the earth and on every bird of the air, on everything that creeps on the ground and on all the fish of the sea; into your hand they are delivered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every moving thing that lives shall be food for you, and just as I gave you the green plants, I give you everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only, you shall not eat flesh with its life, that is, its blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: For your own lifeblood I will surely require a reckoning: from every animal I will require it and from human beings, each one for the blood of another, I will require a reckoning for human life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever sheds the blood of a human,
    by a human shall that person’s blood be shed,
for in his own image
    God made humans.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And you, be fruitful and multiply, abound on the earth and have dominion over it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Noah and to his sons with him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for me, I am establishing my covenant with you and your descendants after you
speaker: Narrator

text: and with every living creature that is with you, the birds, the domestic animals, and every animal of the earth with you, as many as came out of the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: I establish my covenant with you, that never again shall all flesh be cut off by the waters of a flood, and never again shall there be a flood to destroy the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said, “This is the sign of the covenant that I make between me and you and every living creature that is with you, for all future generations:
speaker: Narrator

text: I have set my bow in the clouds, and it shall be a sign of the covenant between me and the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I bring clouds over the earth and the bow is seen in the clouds,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will remember my covenant that is between me and you and every living creature of all flesh, and the waters shall never again become a flood to destroy all flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the bow is in the clouds, I will see it and remember the everlasting covenant between God and every living creature of all flesh that is on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to Noah, “This is the sign of the covenant that I have established between me and all flesh that is on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Noah who went out of the ark were Shem, Ham, and Japheth. Ham was the father of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These three were the sons of Noah, and from these the whole earth was peopled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah, a man of the soil, was the first to plant a vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: He drank some of the wine and became drunk, and he lay uncovered in his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Ham, the father of Canaan, saw the nakedness of his father and told his two brothers outside.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shem and Japheth took a garment, laid it on both their shoulders, and walked backward and covered the nakedness of their father; their faces were turned away, and they did not see their father’s nakedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Noah awoke from his wine and knew what his youngest son had done to him,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He also said,
“Blessed by the Lord my God be Shem,
    and let Canaan be his slave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May God make space for Japheth,
    and let him live in the tents of Shem,
    and let Canaan be his slave.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the flood Noah lived three hundred fifty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the days of Noah were nine hundred fifty years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the descendants of Noah’s sons, Shem, Ham, and Japheth; children were born to them after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Japheth: Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gomer: Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Javan: Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim.
speaker: Narrator

text: From these the coastland peoples spread. These are the descendants of Japheth in their lands, with their own language, by their families, in their nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Ham: Cush, Egypt, Put, and Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Cush: Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteca. The descendants of Raamah: Sheba and Dedan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cush became the father of Nimrod; he was the first on earth to become a mighty warrior.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was a mighty hunter before the Lord; therefore it is said, “Like Nimrod a mighty hunter before the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The beginning of his kingdom was Babel, Erech, Akkad, and Calneh in the land of Shinar.
speaker: Narrator

text: From that land he went into Assyria and built Nineveh, Rehoboth-ir, Calah, and
speaker: Narrator

text: Resen between Nineveh and Calah; that is the great city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Egypt became the father of Ludim, Anamim, Lehabim, Naphtuhim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Pathrusim, Casluhim, from whom the Philistines come, and Caphtorim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Canaan became the father of Sidon, his firstborn, and Heth
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Hivites, the Arkites, the Sinites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites. Afterward the families of the Canaanites spread abroad.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the territory of the Canaanites extended from Sidon in the direction of Gerar as far as Gaza and in the direction of Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim as far as Lasha.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the descendants of Ham, by their families, their languages, their lands, and their nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Shem also, the father of all the children of Eber, the elder brother of Japheth, children were born.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Shem: Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, and Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Aram: Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arpachshad became the father of Shelah, and Shelah became the father of Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Eber were born two sons: the name of the one was Peleg, for in his days the earth was divided, and his brother’s name was Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joktan became the father of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab; all these were the descendants of Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The territory in which they lived extended from Mesha in the direction of Sephar, the hill country of the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the descendants of Shem, by their families, their languages, their lands, and their nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of Noah’s sons, according to their genealogies, in their nations, and from these the nations spread abroad on the earth after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the whole earth had one language and the same words.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as they migrated from the east, they came upon a plain in the land of Shinar and settled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said to one another, “Come, let us make bricks and fire them thoroughly.” And they had brick for stone and bitumen for mortar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “Come, let us build ourselves a city and a tower with its top in the heavens, and let us make a name for ourselves; otherwise we shall be scattered abroad upon the face of the whole earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord came down to see the city and the tower, which mortals had built.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “Look, they are one people, and they have all one language, and this is only the beginning of what they will do; nothing that they propose to do will now be impossible for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let us go down and confuse their language there, so that they will not understand one another’s speech.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord scattered them abroad from there over the face of all the earth, and they left off building the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore it was called Babel, because there the Lord confused the language of all the earth, and from there the Lord scattered them abroad over the face of all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the descendants of Shem. When Shem was one hundred years old, he became the father of Arpachshad two years after the flood,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Shem lived after the birth of Arpachshad five hundred years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Arpachshad had lived thirty-five years, he became the father of Shelah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Arpachshad lived after the birth of Shelah four hundred three years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Shelah had lived thirty years, he became the father of Eber,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Shelah lived after the birth of Eber four hundred three years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Eber had lived thirty-four years, he became the father of Peleg,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Eber lived after the birth of Peleg four hundred thirty years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Peleg had lived thirty years, he became the father of Reu,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Peleg lived after the birth of Reu two hundred nine years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Reu had lived thirty-two years, he became the father of Serug,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Reu lived after the birth of Serug two hundred seven years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Serug had lived thirty years, he became the father of Nahor,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Serug lived after the birth of Nahor two hundred years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Nahor had lived twenty-nine years, he became the father of Terah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Nahor lived after the birth of Terah one hundred nineteen years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Terah had lived seventy years, he became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these are the descendants of Terah. Terah was the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran, and Haran was the father of Lot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Haran died before his father Terah in the land of his birth, in Ur of the Chaldeans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram and Nahor took wives; the name of Abram’s wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor’s wife was Milcah. She was the daughter of Haran the father of Milcah and Iscah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Sarai was barren; she had no child.
speaker: Narrator

text: Terah took his son Abram and his grandson Lot son of Haran and his daughter-in-law Sarai, his son Abram’s wife, and they went out together from Ur of the Chaldeans to go into the land of Canaan, but when they came to Haran, they settled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The days of Terah were two hundred five years, and Terah died in Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord said to Abram, “Go from your country and your kindred and your father’s house to the land that I will show you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make of you a great nation, and I will bless you and make your name great, so that you will be a blessing.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bless those who bless you, and the one who curses you I will curse, and in you all the families of the earth shall be blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram went, as the Lord had told him, and Lot went with him. Abram was seventy-five years old when he departed from Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram took his wife Sarai and his brother’s son Lot and all the possessions that they had gathered and the persons whom they had acquired in Haran, and they set forth to go to the land of Canaan. When they had come to the land of Canaan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram passed through the land to the place at Shechem, to the oak of Moreh. At that time the Canaanites were in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord appeared to Abram and said, “To your offspring I will give this land.” So he built there an altar to the Lord, who had appeared to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there he moved on to the hill country on the east of Bethel and pitched his tent, with Bethel on the west and Ai on the east, and there he built an altar to the Lord and invoked the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abram journeyed on by stages toward the Negeb.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a famine in the land. So Abram went down to Egypt to reside there as an alien, for the famine was severe in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he was about to enter Egypt, he said to his wife Sarai, “I know well that you are a woman beautiful in appearance,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when the Egyptians see you, they will say, ‘This is his wife’; then they will kill me, but they will let you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say you are my sister, so that it may go well with me because of you and that my life may be spared on your account.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram entered Egypt the Egyptians saw that the woman was very beautiful.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the officials of Pharaoh saw her, they praised her to Pharaoh. And the woman was taken into Pharaoh’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And for her sake he dealt well with Abram, and he had sheep, oxen, male donkeys, male and female slaves, female donkeys, and camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord afflicted Pharaoh and his house with great plagues because of Sarai, Abram’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh called Abram and said, “What is this you have done to me? Why did you not tell me that she was your wife?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you say, ‘She is my sister,’ so that I took her for my wife? Now then, here is your wife, take her, and be gone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Pharaoh gave his men orders concerning him, and they set him on the way with his wife and all that he had.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram went up from Egypt, he and his wife and all that he had and Lot with him, into the Negeb.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abram was very rich in livestock, in silver, and in gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He journeyed on by stages from the Negeb as far as Bethel, to the place where his tent had been at the beginning, between Bethel and Ai,
speaker: Narrator

text: to the place where he had made an altar at the first, and there Abram called on the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Lot, who went with Abram, also had flocks and herds and tents,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the land could not support both of them living together because their possessions were so great that they could not live together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus strife arose between the herders of Abram’s livestock and the herders of Lot’s livestock. At that time the Canaanites and the Perizzites lived in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram said to Lot, “Let there be no strife between you and me and between your herders and my herders, for we are kindred.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not the whole land before you? Separate yourself from me. If you take the left hand, then I will go to the right, or if you take the right hand, then I will go to the left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot looked about him and saw that the plain of the Jordan was well watered everywhere like the garden of the Lord, like the land of Egypt, in the direction of Zoar; this was before the Lord destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Lot chose for himself all the plain of the Jordan, and Lot journeyed eastward, and they separated from each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram settled in the land of Canaan, while Lot settled among the cities of the plain and moved his tent as far as Sodom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the people of Sodom were wicked, great sinners against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Abram, after Lot had separated from him, “Raise your eyes now, and look from the place where you are, northward and southward and eastward and westward,
speaker: Narrator

text: for all the land that you see I will give to you and to your offspring forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your offspring like the dust of the earth, so that if one can count the dust of the earth, your offspring also can be counted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rise up, walk through the length and the breadth of the land, for I will give it to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram moved his tent and came and settled by the oaks of Mamre, which are at Hebron, and there he built an altar to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the days of King Amraphel of Shinar, King Arioch of Ellasar, King Chedorlaomer of Elam, and King Tidal of Goiim,
speaker: Narrator

text: these kings made war with King Bera of Sodom, King Birsha of Gomorrah, King Shinab of Admah, King Shemeber of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela, that is, Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these joined forces in the Valley of Siddim, that is, the Dead Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Twelve years they had served Chedorlaomer, but in the thirteenth year they rebelled.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourteenth year Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him came and subdued the Rephaim in Ashteroth-karnaim, the Zuzim in Ham, the Emim in Shaveh-kiriathaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Horites in the hill country of Seir as far as El-paran on the edge of the wilderness;
speaker: Narrator

text: then they turned back and came to En-mishpat, that is, Kadesh, and subdued all the country of the Amalekites and also the Amorites who lived in Hazazon-tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Sodom, the king of Gomorrah, the king of Admah, the king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela, that is, Zoar, went out, and they joined battle in the Valley of Siddim
speaker: Narrator

text: with King Chedorlaomer of Elam, King Tidal of Goiim, King Amraphel of Shinar, and King Arioch of Ellasar, four kings against five.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Valley of Siddim was full of bitumen pits, and as the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, some fell into them, and the rest fled to the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the enemy took all the goods of Sodom and Gomorrah and all their provisions and went their way;
speaker: Narrator

text: they also took Lot, the son of Abram’s brother, who lived in Sodom, and his goods and departed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one who had escaped came and told Abram the Hebrew, who was living by the oaks of Mamre the Amorite, brother of Eshcol and of Aner; these were allies of Abram.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram heard that his nephew had been taken captive, he led forth his trained men, born in his house, three hundred eighteen of them, and went in pursuit as far as Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He divided his forces against them by night, he and his servants, and routed them and pursued them to Hobah, north of Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought back all the goods and also brought back his nephew Lot with his goods and the women and the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: After his return from the defeat of Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him, the king of Sodom went out to meet him at the Valley of Shaveh, that is, the King’s Valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: And King Melchizedek of Salem brought out bread and wine; he was priest of God Most High.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He blessed him and said,
“Blessed be Abram by God Most High,
    maker of heaven and earth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and blessed be God Most High,
    who has delivered your enemies into your hand!”
And Abram gave him one-tenth of everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Sodom said to Abram, “Give me the persons, but take the goods for yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram said to the king of Sodom, “I have sworn to God Most High, maker of heaven and earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: that I would not take a thread or a sandal strap or anything that is yours, so that you might not say, ‘I have made Abram rich.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take nothing but what the young men have eaten and the share of the men who went with me: Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre. Let them take their share.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After these things the word of the Lord came to Abram in a vision, “Do not be afraid, Abram, I am your shield; your reward shall be very great.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram said, “O Lord God, what will you give me, for I continue childless, and the heir of my house is Eliezer of Damascus?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abram said, “You have given me no offspring, so a slave born in my house is to be my heir.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the word of the Lord came to him, “This man shall not be your heir; no one but your very own issue shall be your heir.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought him outside and said, “Look toward heaven and count the stars, if you are able to count them.” Then he said to him, “So shall your descendants be.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he believed the Lord, and the Lord reckoned it to him as righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to him, “I am the Lord who brought you from Ur of the Chaldeans, to give you this land to possess.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “O Lord God, how am I to know that I shall possess it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “Bring me a heifer three years old, a female goat three years old, a ram three years old, a turtledove, and a young pigeon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought him all these and cut them in two, laying each half over against the other, but he did not cut the birds in two.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when birds of prey came down on the carcasses, Abram drove them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the sun was going down, a deep sleep fell upon Abram, and a deep and terrifying darkness descended upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Abram, “Know this for certain, that your offspring shall be aliens in a land that is not theirs and shall be slaves there, and they shall be oppressed for four hundred years,
speaker: Narrator

text: but I will bring judgment on the nation that they serve, and afterward they shall come out with great possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for yourself, you shall go to your ancestors in peace; you shall be buried in a good old age.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall come back here in the fourth generation, for the iniquity of the Amorites is not yet complete.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sun had gone down and it was dark, a smoking fire pot and a flaming torch passed between these pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Lord made a covenant with Abram, saying, “To your descendants I give this land, from the river of Egypt to the great river, the River Euphrates,
speaker: Narrator

text: the land of the Kenites, the Kenizzites, the Kadmonites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Rephaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Girgashites, and the Jebusites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Sarai, Abram’s wife, bore him no children. She had an Egyptian slave whose name was Hagar,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Sarai said to Abram, “You see that the Lord has prevented me from bearing children; go in to my slave; it may be that I shall obtain children by her.” And Abram listened to the voice of Sarai.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, after Abram had lived ten years in the land of Canaan, Sarai, Abram’s wife, took Hagar the Egyptian, her slave, and gave her to her husband Abram as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went in to Hagar, and she conceived, and when she saw that she had conceived, she looked with contempt on her mistress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Sarai said to Abram, “May the wrong done to me be on you! I gave my slave to your embrace, and when she saw that she had conceived, she looked on me with contempt. May the Lord judge between you and me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram said to Sarai, “Your slave is in your power; do to her as you please.” Then Sarai dealt harshly with her, and she ran away from her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord found her by a spring of water in the wilderness, the spring on the way to Shur.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Hagar, slave of Sarai, where have you come from and where are you going?” She said, “I am running away from my mistress Sarai.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to her, “Return to your mistress, and submit to her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord also said to her, “I will so greatly multiply your offspring that they cannot be counted for multitude.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the angel of the Lord said to her,
“Now you have conceived and shall bear a son;
    you shall call him Ishmael,
    for the Lord has given heed to your affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall be a wild ass of a man,
with his hand against everyone,
    and everyone’s hand against him,
and he shall live at odds with all his kin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she named the Lord who spoke to her, “You are El-roi,” for she said, “Have I really seen God and remained alive after seeing him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the well was called Beer-lahai-roi; it lies between Kadesh and Bered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hagar bore Abram a son, and Abram named his son, whom Hagar bore, Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar bore him Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram was ninety-nine years old, the Lord appeared to Abram and said to him, “I am God Almighty; walk before me, and be blameless.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will make my covenant between me and you and will make you exceedingly numerous.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram fell on his face, and God said to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for me, this is my covenant with you: You shall be the ancestor of a multitude of nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: No longer shall your name be Abram, but your name shall be Abraham, for I have made you the ancestor of a multitude of nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make you exceedingly fruitful, and I will make nations of you, and kings shall come from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will establish my covenant between me and you and your offspring after you throughout their generations, for an everlasting covenant, to be God to you and to your offspring after you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will give to you and to your offspring after you the land where you are now an alien, all the land of Canaan, for a perpetual holding, and I will be their God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to Abraham, “As for you, you shall keep my covenant, you and your offspring after you throughout their generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is my covenant, which you shall keep, between me and you and your offspring after you: Every male among you shall be circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall circumcise the flesh of your foreskins, and it shall be a sign of the covenant between me and you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throughout your generations every male among you shall be circumcised when he is eight days old, including the slave born in your house and the one bought with your money from any foreigner who is not of your offspring.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both the slave born in your house and the one bought with your money must be circumcised. So shall my covenant be in your flesh an everlasting covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any uncircumcised male who is not circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin shall be cut off from his people; he has broken my covenant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to Abraham, “As for Sarai your wife, you shall not call her Sarai, but Sarah shall be her name.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bless her and also give you a son by her. I will bless her, and she shall give rise to nations; kings of peoples shall come from her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham fell on his face and laughed and said to himself, “Can a child be born to a man who is a hundred years old? Can Sarah, who is ninety years old, bear a child?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham said to God, “O that Ishmael might live in your sight!”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said, “No, but your wife Sarah shall bear you a son, and you shall name him Isaac. I will establish my covenant with him as an everlasting covenant for his offspring after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for Ishmael, I have heard you; I will bless him and make him fruitful and exceedingly numerous; he shall be the father of twelve princes, and I will make him a great nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But my covenant I will establish with Isaac, whom Sarah shall bear to you at this season next year.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had finished talking with him, God went up from Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham took his son Ishmael and all the slaves born in his house or bought with his money, every male among the men of Abraham’s house, and he circumcised the flesh of their foreskins that very day, as God had said to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was ninety-nine years old when he was circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin.
speaker: Narrator

text: And his son Ishmael was thirteen years old when he was circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin.
speaker: Narrator

text: That very day Abraham and his son Ishmael were circumcised,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all the men of his house, slaves born in the house and those bought with money from a foreigner, were circumcised with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord appeared to Abraham by the oaks of Mamre, as he sat at the entrance of his tent in the heat of the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked up and saw three men standing near him. When he saw them, he ran from the tent entrance to meet them and bowed down to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “My lord, if I find favor with you, do not pass by your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let a little water be brought, and wash your feet, and rest yourselves under the tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me bring a little bread, that you may refresh yourselves, and after that you may pass on—since you have come to your servant.” So they said, “Do as you have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham hastened into the tent to Sarah and said, “Make ready quickly three measures of choice flour, knead it, and make cakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham ran to the herd and took a calf, tender and good, and gave it to the servant, who hastened to prepare it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took curds and milk and the calf that he had prepared and set it before them, and he stood by them under the tree while they ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Where is your wife Sarah?” And he said, “There, in the tent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one said, “I will surely return to you in due season, and your wife Sarah shall have a son.” And Sarah was listening at the tent entrance behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abraham and Sarah were old, advanced in age; it had ceased to be with Sarah after the manner of women.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Sarah laughed to herself, saying, “After I have grown old, and my husband is old, shall I be fruitful?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Abraham, “Why did Sarah laugh and say, ‘Shall I indeed bear a child, now that I am old?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anything too wonderful for the Lord? At the set time I will return to you, in due season, and Sarah shall have a son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sarah denied, saying, “I did not laugh,” for she was afraid. He said, “Yes, you did laugh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men set out from there, and they looked toward Sodom, and Abraham went with them to set them on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Shall I hide from Abraham what I am about to do,
speaker: Narrator

text: seeing that Abraham shall become a great and mighty nation, and all the nations of the earth shall be blessed in him?
speaker: Narrator

text: No, for I have chosen him, that he may charge his children and his household after him to keep the way of the Lord by doing righteousness and justice, so that the Lord may bring about for Abraham what he has promised him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “How great is the outcry against Sodom and Gomorrah and how very grave their sin!
speaker: Narrator

text: I must go down and see whether they have done altogether according to the outcry that has come to me, and if not, I will know.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men turned from there and went toward Sodom, while Abraham remained standing before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham came near and said, “Will you indeed sweep away the righteous with the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose there are fifty righteous within the city; will you then sweep away the place and not forgive it for the fifty righteous who are in it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Far be it from you to do such a thing, to slay the righteous with the wicked, so that the righteous fare as the wicked! Far be that from you! Shall not the Judge of all the earth do what is just?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “If I find at Sodom fifty righteous in the city, I will forgive the whole place for their sake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham answered, “Let me take it upon myself to speak to my lord, I who am but dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose five of the fifty righteous are lacking? Will you destroy the whole city for lack of five?” And he said, “I will not destroy it if I find forty-five there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again he spoke to him, “Suppose forty are found there.” He answered, “For the sake of forty I will not do it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Oh, do not let my lord be angry if I speak. Suppose thirty are found there.” He answered, “I will not do it, if I find thirty there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Let me take it upon myself to speak to my lord. Suppose twenty are found there.” He answered, “For the sake of twenty I will not destroy it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Oh, do not let my lord be angry if I speak just once more. Suppose ten are found there.” He answered, “For the sake of ten I will not destroy it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord went his way, when he had finished speaking to Abraham, and Abraham returned to his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The two angels came to Sodom in the evening, and Lot was sitting in the gateway of Sodom. When Lot saw them, he rose to meet them and bowed down with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Please, my lords, turn aside to your servant’s house and spend the night and wash your feet; then you can rise early and go on your way.” They said, “No; we will spend the night in the square.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he urged them strongly, so they turned aside to him and entered his house, and he made them a feast and baked unleavened bread, and they ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: But before they lay down, the men of the city, the men of Sodom, both young and old, all the people to the last man, surrounded the house,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they called to Lot, “Where are the men who came to you tonight? Bring them out to us, so that we may know them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot went out of the door to the men, shut the door after him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “I beg you, my brothers, do not act so wickedly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, I have two daughters who have not known a man; let me bring them out to you, and do to them as you please; only do nothing to these men, for they have come under the shelter of my roof.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they replied, “Stand back!” And they said, “This fellow came here as an alien, and he would play the judge! Now we will deal worse with you than with them.” Then they pressed hard against the man Lot and came near the door to break it down.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men inside reached out their hands and brought Lot into the house with them and shut the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they struck with blindness the men who were at the door of the house, both small and great, so that they were unable to find the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men said to Lot, “Have you anyone else here? Sons-in-law, sons, daughters, or anyone you have in the city—bring them out of the place.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we are about to destroy this place, because the outcry against its people has become great before the Lord, and the Lord has sent us to destroy it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Lot went out and said to his sons-in-law, who were to marry his daughters, “Up, get out of this place, for the Lord is about to destroy the city.” But he seemed to his sons-in-law to be jesting.
speaker: Narrator

text: When morning dawned, the angels urged Lot, saying, “Get up, take your wife and your two daughters who are here, or else you will be consumed in the punishment of the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he lingered, so the men seized him and his wife and his two daughters by the hand, the Lord being merciful to him, and they brought him out and left him outside the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had brought them outside, they said, “Flee for your life; do not look back or stop anywhere in the plain; flee to the hills, or else you will be consumed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Lot said to them, “Oh, no, my lords;
speaker: Narrator

text: your servant has found favor with you, and you have shown me great kindness in saving my life, but I cannot flee to the hills, for fear the disaster will overtake me and I die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, that city is near enough to flee to, and it is a little one. Let me escape there—is it not a little one?—and my life will be saved!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “Very well, I grant you this favor too and will not overthrow the city of which you have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hurry, escape there, for I can do nothing until you arrive there.” Therefore the city was called Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sun had risen on the earth when Lot came to Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord rained on Sodom and Gomorrah sulfur and fire from the Lord out of heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he overthrew those cities and all the plain and all the inhabitants of the cities and what grew on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Lot’s wife, behind him, looked back, and she became a pillar of salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham went early in the morning to the place where he had stood before the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he looked down toward Sodom and Gomorrah and toward all the land of the plain and saw the smoke of the land going up like the smoke of a furnace.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it was that, when God destroyed the cities of the plain, God remembered Abraham and sent Lot out of the midst of the overthrow, when he overthrew the cities in which Lot had settled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Lot went up out of Zoar and settled in the hills with his two daughters, for he was afraid to stay in Zoar, so he lived in a cave with his two daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the firstborn said to the younger, “Our father is old, and there is not a man on earth to come in to us after the manner of all the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let us make our father drink wine, and we will lie with him, so that we may preserve offspring through our father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they made their father drink wine that night, and the firstborn went in and lay with her father; he did not know when she lay down or when she rose.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day, the firstborn said to the younger, “Look, I lay last night with my father; let us make him drink wine tonight also; then you go in and lie with him, so that we may preserve offspring through our father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they made their father drink wine that night also, and the younger rose and lay with him, and he did not know when she lay down or when she rose.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus both the daughters of Lot became pregnant by their father.
speaker: Narrator

text: The firstborn bore a son and named him Moab; he is the ancestor of the Moabites to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The younger also bore a son and named him Ben-ammi; he is the ancestor of the Ammonites to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there Abraham journeyed toward the region of the Negeb and settled between Kadesh and Shur. While residing in Gerar as an alien,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said of his wife Sarah, “She is my sister.” And King Abimelech of Gerar sent and took Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God came to Abimelech in a dream by night and said to him, “You are about to die because of the woman whom you have taken, for she is a married woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abimelech had not approached her, so he said, “Lord, will you destroy an innocent people?
speaker: Narrator

text: Did he not himself say to me, ‘She is my sister’? And she herself said, ‘He is my brother.’ I did this in the integrity of my heart and the innocence of my hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to him in the dream, “Yes, I know that you did this in the integrity of your heart; furthermore, it was I who kept you from sinning against me. Therefore I did not let you touch her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, return the man’s wife, for he is a prophet, and he will pray for you, and you shall live. But if you do not restore her, know that you shall surely die, you and all that are yours.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech rose early in the morning and called all his servants and told them all these things, and the men were very much afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech called Abraham and said to him, “What have you done to us? How have I sinned against you, that you have brought such great guilt on me and my kingdom? You have done things to me that ought not to be done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abimelech said to Abraham, “What were you thinking, that you did this thing?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said, “I did it because I thought, Surely there is no fear of God in this place, and they will kill me because of my wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Besides, she is indeed my sister, the daughter of my father but not the daughter of my mother, and she became my wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when God caused me to wander from my father’s house, I said to her, ‘This is the kindness you must do me: at every place to which we come, say of me, He is my brother.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech took sheep and oxen and male and female slaves and gave them to Abraham and restored his wife Sarah to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech said, “My land is before you; settle where it pleases you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: To Sarah he said, “Look, I have given your brother a thousand pieces of silver; it is your exoneration before all who are with you; you are completely vindicated.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham prayed to God, and God healed Abimelech and also healed his wife and female slaves so that they bore children.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had closed fast all the wombs of the house of Abimelech because of Sarah, Abraham’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord dealt with Sarah as he had said, and the Lord did for Sarah as he had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sarah conceived and bore Abraham a son in his old age, at the time of which God had spoken to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham gave the name Isaac to his son whom Sarah bore him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham circumcised his son Isaac when he was eight days old, as God had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was a hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Sarah said, “God has brought laughter for me; everyone who hears will laugh with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And she said, “Who would ever have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet I have borne him a son in his old age.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The child grew and was weaned, and Abraham made a great feast on the day that Isaac was weaned.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sarah saw the son of Hagar the Egyptian, whom she had borne to Abraham, playing with her son Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: So she said to Abraham, “Cast out this slave woman with her son, for the son of this slave woman shall not inherit along with my son Isaac.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The matter was very distressing to Abraham on account of his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God said to Abraham, “Do not be distressed because of the boy and because of your slave woman; whatever Sarah says to you, do as she tells you, for it is through Isaac that offspring shall be named for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the son of the slave woman, I will make a nation of him also, because he is your offspring.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham rose early in the morning and took bread and a skin of water and gave it to Hagar, putting it on her shoulder, along with the child, and sent her away. And she departed and wandered about in the wilderness of Beer-sheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the water in the skin was gone, she cast the child under one of the bushes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she went and sat down opposite him a good way off, about the distance of a bowshot, for she said, “Do not let me look on the death of the child.” And as she sat opposite him, she lifted up her voice and wept.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God heard the voice of the boy, and the angel of God called to Hagar from heaven and said to her, “What troubles you, Hagar? Do not be afraid, for God has heard the voice of the boy where he is.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, lift up the boy and hold him fast with your hand, for I will make a great nation of him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God opened her eyes, and she saw a well of water. She went and filled the skin with water and gave the boy a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: God was with the boy, and he grew up; he lived in the wilderness and became an expert with the bow.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lived in the wilderness of Paran, and his mother got a wife for him from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Abimelech, with Phicol the commander of his army, said to Abraham, “God is with you in all that you do;
speaker: Narrator

text: now therefore swear to me here by God that you will not deal falsely with me or with my offspring or with my posterity, but as I have dealt loyally with you, you will deal with me and with the land where you have resided as an alien.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham said, “I swear it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abraham complained to Abimelech about a well of water that Abimelech’s servants had seized,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech said, “I do not know who has done this; you did not tell me, and I have not heard of it until today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham took sheep and oxen and gave them to Abimelech, and the two men made a covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham set apart seven ewe lambs of the flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abimelech said to Abraham, “What is the meaning of these seven ewe lambs that you have set apart?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “These seven ewe lambs you shall accept from my hand in order that you may be a witness for me that I dug this well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore that place was called Beer-sheba, because there both of them swore an oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had made a covenant at Beer-sheba, Abimelech, with Phicol the commander of his army, left and returned to the land of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham planted a tamarisk tree in Beer-sheba and there called on the name of the Lord, the Everlasting God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham resided as an alien many days in the land of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: After these things God tested Abraham. He said to him, “Abraham!” And he said, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Take your son, your only son Isaac, whom you love, and go to the land of Moriah and offer him there as a burnt offering on one of the mountains that I shall show you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham rose early in the morning, saddled his donkey, and took two of his young men with him and his son Isaac; he cut the wood for the burnt offering and set out and went to the place in the distance that God had shown him.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day Abraham looked up and saw the place far away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham said to his young men, “Stay here with the donkey; the boy and I will go over there; we will worship, and then we will come back to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham took the wood of the burnt offering and laid it on his son Isaac, and he himself carried the fire and the knife. And the two of them walked on together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac said to his father Abraham, “Father!” And he said, “Here I am, my son.” He said, “The fire and the wood are here, but where is the lamb for a burnt offering?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said, “God himself will provide the lamb for a burnt offering, my son.” And the two of them walked on together.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to the place that God had shown him, Abraham built an altar there and laid the wood in order. He bound his son Isaac and laid him on the altar on top of the wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham reached out his hand and took the knife to kill his son.
speaker: Narrator
