text: But the angel of the Lord called to him from heaven and said, “Abraham, Abraham!” And he said, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Do not lay your hand on the boy or do anything to him, for now I know that you fear God, since you have not withheld your son, your only son, from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham looked up and saw a ram, caught in a thicket by its horns. Abraham went and took the ram and offered it up as a burnt offering instead of his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham called that place “The Lord will provide,” as it is said to this day, “On the mount of the Lord it shall be provided.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord called to Abraham a second time from heaven
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “By myself I have sworn, says the Lord: Because you have done this, and have not withheld your son, your only son,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will indeed bless you, and I will make your offspring as numerous as the stars of heaven and as the sand that is on the seashore. And your offspring shall possess the gate of their enemies,
speaker: Narrator

text: and by your offspring shall all the nations of the earth gain blessing for themselves, because you have obeyed my voice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham returned to his young men, and they arose and went together to Beer-sheba, and Abraham lived at Beer-sheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now after these things it was told Abraham, “Milcah also has borne children to your brother Nahor:
speaker: Narrator

text: Uz the firstborn, Buz his brother, Kemuel the father of Aram,
speaker: Narrator

text: Chesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Bethuel became the father of Rebekah. These eight Milcah bore to Nahor, Abraham’s brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, his concubine, whose name was Reumah, bore Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sarah lived one hundred twenty-seven years; this was the length of Sarah’s life.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Sarah died at Kiriath-arba, that is, Hebron, in the land of Canaan, and Abraham went in to mourn for Sarah and to weep for her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham rose up from beside his dead and said to the Hittites,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am a stranger and an alien residing among you; give me property among you for a burying place, so that I may bury my dead out of my sight.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Hittites answered Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Hear us, my lord; you are a mighty prince among us. Bury your dead in the choicest of our burial places; none of us will withhold from you any burial ground for burying your dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham rose and bowed to the Hittites, the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “If you are willing that I should bury my dead out of my sight, hear me and entreat for me Ephron son of Zohar,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that he may give me the cave of Machpelah, which he owns; it is at the end of his field. For the full price let him give it to me in your presence as a possession for a burying place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ephron was sitting among the Hittites, and Ephron the Hittite answered Abraham in the hearing of the Hittites, of all who went in at the gate of his city,
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, my lord, hear me; I give you the field, and I give you the cave that is in it; in the presence of my people I give it to you; bury your dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham bowed down before the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to Ephron in the hearing of the people of the land, “If you only will listen to me! I will give the price of the field; accept it from me, so that I may bury my dead there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephron answered Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: “My lord, listen to me; a piece of land worth four hundred shekels of silver—what is that between you and me? Bury your dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham agreed with Ephron, and Abraham weighed out for Ephron the silver that he had named in the hearing of the Hittites, four hundred shekels of silver, according to the weights current among the merchants.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the field of Ephron in Machpelah, which was to the east of Mamre, the field with the cave that was in it and all the trees that were in the field, throughout its whole area, passed
speaker: Narrator

text: to Abraham as a possession in the presence of the Hittites, in the presence of all who went in at the gate of his city.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Abraham buried Sarah his wife in the cave of the field of Machpelah facing Mamre, that is, Hebron, in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The field and the cave that is in it passed from the Hittites into Abraham’s possession as a burying place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abraham was old, advanced in years, and the Lord had blessed Abraham in all things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said to his servant, the oldest of his house, who had charge of all that he had, “Put your hand under my thigh,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I will make you swear by the Lord, the God of heaven and earth, that you will not get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I live,
speaker: Narrator

text: but will go to my country and to my kindred and get a wife for my son Isaac.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant said to him, “Perhaps the woman may not be willing to follow me to this land; must I then take your son back to the land from which you came?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said to him, “See to it that you do not take my son back there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord, the God of heaven, who took me from my father’s house and from the land of my birth and who spoke to me and swore to me, ‘To your offspring I will give this land,’ he will send his angel before you, and you shall take a wife for my son from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the woman is not willing to follow you, then you will be free from this oath of mine; only you must not take my son back there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the servant put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master and swore to him concerning this matter.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant took ten of his master’s camels and departed, taking all kinds of choice gifts from his master, and he set out and went to Aram-naharaim, to the city of Nahor.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the camels kneel down outside the city by the well of water; it was toward evening, the time when women go out to draw water.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “O Lord, God of my master Abraham, please grant me success today and show steadfast love to my master Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am standing here by the spring of water, and the daughters of the townspeople are coming out to draw water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the young woman to whom I shall say, ‘Please offer your jar that I may drink,’ and who shall say, ‘Drink, and I will water your camels’—let her be the one whom you have appointed for your servant Isaac. By this I shall know that you have shown steadfast love to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Before he had finished speaking, there was Rebekah, who was born to Bethuel son of Milcah, the wife of Nahor, Abraham’s brother, coming out with her water jar on her shoulder.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young woman was very fair to look upon, a virgin, whom no man had known. She went down to the spring, filled her jar, and came up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant ran to meet her and said, “Please let me sip a little water from your jar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Drink, my lord,” she said and quickly lowered her jar upon her hand and gave him a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she had finished giving him a drink, she said, “I will draw for your camels also, until they have finished drinking.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she quickly emptied her jar into the trough and ran again to the well to draw, and she drew for all his camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man gazed at her in silence to learn whether or not the Lord had made his journey successful.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the camels had finished drinking, the man took a gold nose ring weighing a half shekel and two bracelets for her arms weighing ten gold shekels
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “Tell me whose daughter you are. Is there room in your father’s house for us to spend the night?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to him, “I am the daughter of Bethuel son of Milcah, whom she bore to Nahor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She added, “We have plenty of straw and fodder and a place to spend the night.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man bowed his head and worshiped the Lord
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “Blessed be the Lord, the God of my master Abraham, who has not forsaken his steadfast love and his faithfulness toward my master. As for me, the Lord has led me on the way to the house of my master’s kin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the young woman ran and told her mother’s household about these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rebekah had a brother whose name was Laban, and Laban ran out to the man, to the spring.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he had seen the nose ring and the bracelets on his sister’s arms and when he heard the words of his sister Rebekah, “Thus the man spoke to me,” he went to the man, and there he was, standing by the camels at the spring.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Come in, O blessed of the Lord. Why do you stand outside when I have prepared the house and a place for the camels?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the man came into the house, and Laban unloaded the camels and gave him straw and fodder for the camels and water to wash his feet and the feet of the men who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then food was set before him to eat, but he said, “I will not eat until I have told my errand.” He said, “Speak on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said, “I am Abraham’s servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has greatly blessed my master, and he has become wealthy; he has given him flocks and herds, silver and gold, male and female slaves, camels and donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Sarah my master’s wife bore a son to my master when she was old, and he has given him all that he has.
speaker: Narrator

text: My master made me swear, saying, ‘You shall not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites in whose land I live,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you shall go to my father’s house, to my kindred, and get a wife for my son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to my master, ‘Perhaps the woman will not follow me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said to me, ‘The Lord, before whom I walk, will send his angel with you and make your way successful. You shall get a wife for my son from my kindred, from my father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will be free from my oath, when you come to my kindred; even if they will not give her to you, you will be free from my oath.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I came today to the spring and said, ‘O Lord, God of my master Abraham, if now you will only make successful the way I am going!
speaker: Narrator

text: I am standing here by the spring of water; let the young woman who comes out to draw, to whom I shall say, “Please give me a little water from your jar to drink,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and who will say to me, “Drink, and I will draw for your camels also”—let her be the woman whom the Lord has appointed for my master’s son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Before I had finished speaking in my heart, there was Rebekah coming out with her water jar on her shoulder, and she went down to the spring and drew. I said to her, ‘Please let me drink.’
speaker: Narrator

text: She quickly let down her jar from her shoulder and said, ‘Drink, and I will also water your camels.’ So I drank, and she also watered the camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I asked her, ‘Whose daughter are you?’ She said, ‘The daughter of Bethuel, Nahor’s son, whom Milcah bore to him.’ So I put the ring on her nose and the bracelets on her arms.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I bowed my head and worshiped the Lord and blessed the Lord, the God of my master Abraham, who had led me by the right way to obtain the daughter of my master’s kinsman for his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, if you will deal loyally and truly with my master, tell me; and if not, tell me, so that I may turn either to the right hand or to the left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban and Bethuel answered, “The thing comes from the Lord; we cannot speak to you anything bad or good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, Rebekah is before you, take her and go, and let her be the wife of your master’s son, as the Lord has spoken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abraham’s servant heard their words, he bowed himself to the ground before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the servant brought out jewelry of silver and of gold and garments and gave them to Rebekah; he also gave to her brother and to her mother costly ornaments.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he and the men who were with him ate and drank, and they spent the night there. When they rose in the morning, he said, “Send me back to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Her brother and her mother said, “Let the young woman remain with us a while, at least ten days; after that she may go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said to them, “Do not delay me, since the Lord has made my journey successful; let me go that I may go to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “We will call the young woman and ask her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they called Rebekah and said to her, “Will you go with this man?” She said, “I will.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sent away their sister Rebekah and her nurse along with Abraham’s servant and his men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And they blessed Rebekah and said to her,
“May you, our sister, become
    thousands of myriads;
may your offspring gain possession
    of the gates of their foes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah and her maids rose up, mounted the camels, and followed the man, and the servant took Rebekah and went his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Isaac had come from Beer-lahai-roi and was settled in the Negeb.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac went out in the evening to walk in the field, and, looking up, he saw camels coming.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Rebekah looked up, and when she saw Isaac, she slipped quickly from the camel
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to the servant, “Who is the man over there, walking in the field to meet us?” The servant said, “It is my master.” So she took her veil and covered herself.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the servant told Isaac all the things that he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac brought her into his mother Sarah’s tent. He took Rebekah, and she became his wife, and he loved her. So Isaac was comforted after his mother’s death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham took another wife, whose name was Keturah.
speaker: Narrator

text: She bore him Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jokshan was the father of Sheba and Dedan. The sons of Dedan were Asshurim, Letushim, and Leummim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were the children of Keturah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham gave all he had to Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to the sons of his concubines Abraham gave gifts, while he was still living, and he sent them away from his son Isaac, eastward to the east country.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the length of Abraham’s life, one hundred seventy-five years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham breathed his last and died in a good old age, old and full of years, and was gathered to his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah, in the field of Ephron son of Zohar the Hittite, east of Mamre,
speaker: Narrator

text: the field that Abraham purchased from the Hittites. There Abraham was buried with his wife Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the death of Abraham, God blessed his son Isaac. And Isaac settled at Beer-lahai-roi.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the descendants of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah’s slave, bore to Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the sons of Ishmael, named in the order of their birth: Nebaioth, the firstborn of Ishmael; and Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Ishmael, and these are their names, by their villages and by their encampments, twelve princes according to their tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: (This is the length of the life of Ishmael, one hundred thirty-seven years; he breathed his last and died and was gathered to his people.)
speaker: Narrator

text: They settled from Havilah to Shur, which is opposite Egypt in the direction of Assyria; he settled down alongside all his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the descendants of Isaac, Abraham’s son: Abraham was the father of Isaac,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Isaac was forty years old when he married Rebekah, daughter of Bethuel the Aramean of Paddan-aram, sister of Laban the Aramean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac prayed to the Lord for his wife because she was barren, and the Lord granted his prayer, and his wife Rebekah conceived.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children struggled together within her, and she said, “If it is to be this way, why do I live?” So she went to inquire of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: When her time to give birth was at hand, there were twins in her womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first came out red, all his body like a hairy mantle, so they named him Esau.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward his brother came out, with his hand gripping Esau’s heel, so he was named Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when she bore them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the boys grew up, Esau was a skillful hunter, a man of the field, while Jacob was a quiet man, living in tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac loved Esau because he was fond of game, but Rebekah loved Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once when Jacob was cooking a stew, Esau came in from the field, and he was famished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said to Jacob, “Let me eat some of that red stuff, for I am famished!” (Therefore he was called Edom.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said, “First sell me your birthright.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said, “I am about to die; of what use is a birthright to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said, “Swear to me first.” So he swore to him and sold his birthright to Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob gave Esau bread and lentil stew, and he ate and drank and rose and went his way. Thus Esau despised his birthright.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a famine in the land, besides the former famine that had occurred in the days of Abraham. And Isaac went to Gerar, to King Abimelech of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord appeared to Isaac and said, “Do not go down to Egypt; settle in the land that I shall show you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Reside in this land as an alien, and I will be with you and will bless you, for to you and to your descendants I will give all these lands, and I will fulfill the oath that I swore to your father Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your offspring as numerous as the stars of heaven and will give to your offspring all these lands, and all the nations of the earth shall gain blessing for themselves through your offspring,
speaker: Narrator

text: because Abraham obeyed my voice and kept my charge, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac settled in Gerar.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of the place asked him about his wife, he said, “She is my sister,” for he was afraid to say “my wife,” thinking, “or else the men of the place might kill me for the sake of Rebekah, because she is attractive in appearance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Isaac had been there a long time, King Abimelech of the Philistines looked out of a window and saw him fondling his wife Rebekah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech called for Isaac and said, “So she is your wife! Why, then, did you say, ‘She is my sister’?” Isaac said to him, “Because I thought I might die because of her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech said, “What is this you have done to us? One of the people might easily have lain with your wife, and you would have brought guilt upon us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech warned all the people, saying, “Whoever touches this man or his wife shall be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac sowed seed in that land and in the same year reaped a hundredfold. The Lord blessed him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the man became rich; he prospered more and more until he became very wealthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had possessions of flocks and herds and a great household, so that the Philistines envied him.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now the Philistines had stopped up and filled with earth all the wells that his father’s servants had dug in the days of his father Abraham.)
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abimelech said to Isaac, “Go away from us; you have become too powerful for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac departed from there and camped in the Wadi Gerar and settled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac dug again the wells of water that had been dug in the days of his father Abraham, for the Philistines had stopped them up after the death of Abraham, and he gave them the names that his father had given them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Isaac’s servants dug in the valley and found there a well of spring water,
speaker: Narrator

text: the herders of Gerar quarreled with Isaac’s herders, saying, “The water is ours.” So he called the well Esek, because they contended with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they dug another well, and they quarreled over that one also, so he called it Sitnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He moved from there and dug another well, and they did not quarrel over it, so he called it Rehoboth, saying, “Now the Lord has made room for us, and we shall be fruitful in the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: From there he went up to Beer-sheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: And that very night the Lord appeared to him and said, “I am the God of your father Abraham; do not be afraid, for I am with you and will bless you and make your offspring numerous for my servant Abraham’s sake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he built an altar there, called on the name of the Lord, and pitched his tent there. And there Isaac’s servants dug a well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech went to him from Gerar, with Ahuzzath his adviser and Phicol the commander of his army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac said to them, “Why have you come to me, seeing that you hate me and have sent me away from you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “We see plainly that the Lord has been with you, so we say, let there be an oath between you and us, and let us make a covenant with you
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you will do us no harm, just as we have not touched you and have done to you nothing but good and have sent you away in peace. You are now the blessed of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he made them a feast, and they ate and drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning they rose early and exchanged oaths, and Isaac set them on their way, and they departed from him in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day Isaac’s servants came and told him about the well that they had dug and said to him, “We have found water!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He called it Shibah; therefore the name of the city is Beer-sheba to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Esau was forty years old, he married Judith daughter of Beeri the Hittite and Basemath daughter of Elon the Hittite,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they made life bitter for Isaac and Rebekah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Isaac was old and his eyes were dim so that he could not see, he called his elder son Esau and said to him, “My son,” and he answered, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “See, I am old; I do not know the day of my death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, take your weapons, your quiver and your bow, and go out to the field, and hunt game for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then prepare for me savory food, such as I like, and bring it to me to eat, so that I may bless you before I die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Rebekah was listening when Isaac spoke to his son Esau. So when Esau went to the field to hunt for game for his father,
speaker: Narrator

text: Rebekah said to her son Jacob, “I heard your father say to your brother Esau,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Bring me game, and prepare for me savory food to eat, that I may bless you before the Lord before I die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, my son, obey my word as I command you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to the flock, and get me two choice kids, so that I may prepare from them savory food for your father, such as he likes,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you shall take it to your father to eat, so that he may bless you before he dies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob said to his mother Rebekah, “Look, my brother Esau is a hairy man, and I am a man of smooth skin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perhaps my father will feel me, and I shall seem to be mocking him and bring a curse on myself and not a blessing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His mother said to him, “Let your curse be on me, my son; only obey my word, and go, get them for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went and got them and brought them to his mother, and his mother prepared savory food, such as his father loved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah took the best garments of her elder son Esau, which were with her in the house, and put them on her younger son Jacob,
speaker: Narrator

text: and she put the skins of the kids on his hands and on the smooth part of his neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she handed the savory food and the bread that she had prepared to her son Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went in to his father and said, “My father,” and he said, “Here I am; who are you, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said to his father, “I am Esau your firstborn. I have done as you told me; now sit up and eat of my game, so that you may bless me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Isaac said to his son, “How is it that you have found it so quickly, my son?” He answered, “Because the Lord your God granted me success.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Come near, that I may feel you, my son, to know whether you are really my son Esau or not.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob went up to his father Isaac, who felt him and said, “The voice is Jacob’s voice, but the hands are the hands of Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not recognize him because his hands were hairy like his brother Esau’s hands, so he blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Are you really my son Esau?” He answered, “I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Bring it to me, that I may eat of my son’s game and bless you.” So he brought it to him, and he ate, and he brought him wine, and he drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his father Isaac said to him, “Come near and kiss me, my son.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he came near and kissed him, and he smelled the smell of his garments and blessed him and said,
“Ah, the smell of my son
    is like the smell of a field that the Lord has blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May God give you of the dew of heaven
    and of the fatness of the earth
    and plenty of grain and wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let peoples serve you
    and nations bow down to you.
Be lord over your brothers,
    and may your mother’s sons bow down to you.
Cursed be everyone who curses you,
    and blessed be everyone who blesses you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Isaac had finished blessing Jacob, when Jacob had scarcely gone out from the presence of his father Isaac, his brother Esau came in from his hunting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also prepared savory food and brought it to his father. And he said to his father, “Let my father sit up and eat of his son’s game, so that you may bless me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His father Isaac said to him, “Who are you?” He answered, “I am your firstborn son, Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac trembled violently and said, “Who was it then that hunted game and brought it to me, and I ate it all before you came, and I have blessed him?—yes, and blessed he shall be!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Esau heard his father’s words, he cried out with an exceedingly great and bitter cry and said to his father, “Bless me, me also, father!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “Your brother came deceitfully, and he has taken away your blessing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said, “Is he not rightly named Jacob? For he has supplanted me these two times. He took away my birthright, and look, now he has taken away my blessing.” Then he said, “Have you not reserved a blessing for me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac answered Esau, “I have already made him your lord, and I have given him all his brothers as servants, and with grain and wine I have sustained him. What then can I do for you, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said to his father, “Have you only one blessing, father? Bless me, me also, father!” And Esau lifted up his voice and wept.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then his father Isaac answered him:
“See, away from the fatness of the earth shall your home be
    and away from the dew of heaven on high.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By your sword you shall live,
    and you shall serve your brother,
but when you break loose,
    you shall break his yoke from your neck.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing with which his father had blessed him, and Esau said to himself, “The days of mourning for my father are approaching; then I will kill my brother Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the words of her elder son Esau were told to Rebekah, so she sent and called her younger son Jacob and said to him, “Your brother Esau is consoling himself by planning to kill you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, my son, obey my voice; flee at once to my brother Laban in Haran,
speaker: Narrator

text: and stay with him a while, until your brother’s fury turns away—
speaker: Narrator

text: until your brother’s anger against you turns away, and he forgets what you have done to him; then I will send and bring you back from there. Why should I lose both of you in one day?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah said to Isaac, “I am weary of my life because of the Hittite women. If Jacob marries one of the Hittite women such as these, one of the women of the land, what good will my life be to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac called Jacob and blessed him and charged him, “You shall not marry one of the Canaanite women.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go at once to Paddan-aram to the house of Bethuel, your mother’s father, and take as wife from there one of the daughters of Laban, your mother’s brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: May God Almighty bless you and make you fruitful and numerous, that you may become a company of peoples.
speaker: Narrator

text: May he give to you the blessing of Abraham, to you and to your offspring with you, so that you may take possession of the land where you now live as an alien, land that God gave to Abraham.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus Isaac sent Jacob away, and he went to Paddan-aram, to Laban son of Bethuel the Aramean, the brother of Rebekah, Jacob’s and Esau’s mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Esau saw that Isaac had blessed Jacob and sent him away to Paddan-aram to take a wife from there and that as he blessed him he charged him, “You shall not marry one of the Canaanite women,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and that Jacob had obeyed his father and his mother and gone to Paddan-aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when Esau saw that the Canaanite women did not please his father Isaac,
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau went to Ishmael and took Mahalath daughter of Abraham’s son Ishmael and sister of Nebaioth to be his wife in addition to the wives he had.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob left Beer-sheba and went toward Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to a certain place and stayed there for the night, because the sun had set. Taking one of the stones of the place, he put it under his head and lay down in that place.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he dreamed that there was a stairway set up on the earth, the top of it reaching to heaven, and the angels of God were ascending and descending on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord stood beside him and said, “I am the Lord, the God of Abraham your father and the God of Isaac; the land on which you lie I will give to you and to your offspring,
speaker: Narrator

text: and your offspring shall be like the dust of the earth, and you shall spread abroad to the west and to the east and to the north and to the south, and all the families of the earth shall be blessed in you and in your offspring.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know that I am with you and will keep you wherever you go and will bring you back to this land, for I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob woke from his sleep and said, “Surely the Lord is in this place—and I did not know it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he was afraid and said, “How awesome is this place! This is none other than the house of God, and this is the gate of heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob rose early in the morning, and he took the stone that he had put under his head and set it up for a pillar and poured oil on the top of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called that place Bethel, but the name of the city was Luz at the first.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob made a vow, saying, “If God will be with me and will keep me in this way that I go and will give me bread to eat and clothing to wear,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that I come again to my father’s house in peace, then the Lord shall be my God,
speaker: Narrator

text: and this stone, which I have set up for a pillar, shall be God’s house, and of all that you give me I will surely give one-tenth to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob went on his journey and came to the land of the people of the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he looked, he saw a well in the field and three flocks of sheep lying there beside it, for out of that well the flocks were watered. The stone on the well’s mouth was large,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when all the flocks were gathered there, the shepherds would roll the stone from the mouth of the well and water the sheep and put the stone back in its place on the mouth of the well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said to them, “My brothers, where do you come from?” They said, “We are from Haran.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Do you know Laban son of Nahor?” They said, “We do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Is it well with him?” “Yes,” they replied, “and here is his daughter Rachel, coming with the sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Look, it is still broad daylight; it is not time for the animals to be gathered together. Water the sheep, and go, pasture them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they said, “We cannot until all the flocks are gathered together, and the stone is rolled from the mouth of the well; then we water the sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking with them, Rachel came with her father’s sheep, for she kept them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Jacob saw Rachel, the daughter of his mother’s brother Laban, and the sheep of his mother’s brother Laban, Jacob went up and rolled the stone from the well’s mouth and watered the flock of his mother’s brother Laban.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob kissed Rachel and wept aloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob told Rachel that he was her father’s kinsman and that he was Rebekah’s son, and she ran and told her father.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Laban heard the news about his sister’s son Jacob, he ran to meet him; he embraced him and kissed him and brought him to his house. Jacob told Laban all these things,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Laban said to him, “Surely you are my bone and my flesh!” And he stayed with him a month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban said to Jacob, “Because you are my kinsman, should you therefore serve me for nothing? Tell me, what shall your wages be?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Laban had two daughters; the name of the elder was Leah, and the name of the younger was Rachel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah’s eyes were weak, but Rachel was graceful and beautiful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob loved Rachel, so he said, “I will serve you seven years for your younger daughter Rachel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “It is better that I give her to you than that I should give her to any other man; stay with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob served seven years for Rachel, and they seemed to him but a few days because of his love for her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said to Laban, “Give me my wife that I may go in to her, for my time is completed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Laban gathered together all the people of the place and made a feast.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the evening he took his daughter Leah and brought her to Jacob, and he went in to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Laban gave his maid Zilpah to his daughter Leah to be her maid.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When morning came, it was Leah! And Jacob said to Laban, “What is this you have done to me? Did I not serve with you for Rachel? Why then have you deceived me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “This is not done in our country—giving the younger before the firstborn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Complete the week of this one, and we will give you the other also in return for serving me another seven years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob did so and completed her week; then Laban gave him his daughter Rachel as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Laban gave his maid Bilhah to his daughter Rachel to be her maid.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob went in to Rachel also, and he loved Rachel more than Leah. He served Laban for another seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord saw that Leah was unloved, he opened her womb, but Rachel was barren.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah conceived and bore a son, and she named him Reuben, for she said, “Because the Lord has looked on my affliction, surely now my husband will love me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She conceived again and bore a son and said, “Because the Lord has heard that I am hated, he has given me this son also,” and she named him Simeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again she conceived and bore a son and said, “Now this time my husband will be joined to me, because I have borne him three sons”; therefore he was named Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: She conceived again and bore a son and said, “This time I will praise the Lord,” therefore she named him Judah; then she ceased bearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rachel saw that she bore Jacob no children, she envied her sister, and she said to Jacob, “Give me children, or I shall die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob became very angry with Rachel and said, “Am I in the place of God, who has withheld from you the fruit of the womb?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said, “Here is my maid Bilhah; go in to her, that she may bear upon my knees and that I too may have children through her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she gave him her maid Bilhah as a wife, and Jacob went in to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Bilhah conceived and bore Jacob a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rachel said, “God has judged me and has also heard my voice and given me a son”; therefore she named him Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel’s maid Bilhah conceived again and bore Jacob a second son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rachel said, “With mighty wrestlings I have wrestled with my sister and have prevailed,” so she named him Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Leah saw that she had ceased bearing children, she took her maid Zilpah and gave her to Jacob as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Leah’s maid Zilpah bore Jacob a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Leah said, “Good fortune!” So she named him Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah’s maid Zilpah bore Jacob a second son.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Leah said, “Happy am I! For the women will call me happy,” so she named him Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the days of wheat harvest Reuben went and found mandrakes in the field and brought them to his mother Leah. Then Rachel said to Leah, “Please give me some of your son’s mandrakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But she said to her, “Is it a small matter that you have taken away my husband? Would you take away my son’s mandrakes also?” Rachel said, “Then he may lie with you tonight for your son’s mandrakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob came from the field in the evening, Leah went out to meet him and said, “You must come in to me, for I have hired you with my son’s mandrakes.” So he lay with her that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God heeded Leah, and she conceived and bore Jacob a fifth son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah said, “God has given me my hire because I gave my maid to my husband,” so she named him Issachar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Leah conceived again, and she bore Jacob a sixth son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Leah said, “God has endowed me with a good gift; now my husband will honor me, because I have borne him six sons,” so she named him Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards she bore a daughter and named her Dinah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God remembered Rachel, and God heeded her and opened her womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: She conceived and bore a son and said, “God has taken away my reproach,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and she named him Joseph, saying, “May the Lord add to me another son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rachel had borne Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, “Send me away, that I may go to my own home and country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give me my wives and my children for whom I have served you, and let me go, for you know very well the service I have given you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Laban said to him, “If you will allow me to say so, I have learned by divination that the Lord has blessed me because of you;
speaker: Narrator

text: name your wages, and I will give it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said to him, “You yourself know how I have served you and how your livestock have fared with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you had little before I came, and it has increased abundantly, and the Lord has blessed you wherever I turned. But now when shall I provide for my own household also?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “What shall I give you?” Jacob said, “You shall not give me anything; if you will do this for me, I will again feed your flock and keep it:
speaker: Narrator

text: let me pass through all your flock today, removing from it every speckled and spotted sheep and every black lamb and the spotted and speckled among the goats, and such shall be my wages.
speaker: Narrator

text: So my honesty will answer for me later, when you come to look into my wages with you. Every one that is not speckled and spotted among the goats and black among the lambs, if found with me, shall be counted stolen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “Good! Let it be as you have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But that day Laban removed the male goats that were striped and spotted, and all the female goats that were speckled and spotted, every one that had white on it, and every lamb that was black and put them in charge of his sons,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he set a distance of three days’ journey between himself and Jacob, while Jacob was pasturing the rest of Laban’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob took fresh rods of poplar and almond and plane and peeled white streaks in them, exposing the white of the rods.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set the rods that he had peeled in front of the flocks in the troughs, that is, the watering places, where the flocks came to drink. And since they bred when they came to drink,
speaker: Narrator

text: the flocks bred in front of the rods, and so the flocks produced young that were striped, speckled, and spotted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob separated the lambs and set the faces of the flocks toward the striped and the completely black animals in the flock of Laban, and he put his own droves apart and did not put them with Laban’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the stronger of the flock were breeding, Jacob laid the rods in the troughs before the eyes of the flock, that they might breed among the rods,
speaker: Narrator

text: but for the feebler of the flock he did not lay them there, so the feebler were Laban’s and the stronger Jacob’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus the man grew exceedingly rich and had large flocks and male and female slaves and camels and donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jacob heard that the sons of Laban were saying, “Jacob has taken all that was our father’s; he has gained all this wealth from what belonged to our father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob saw that Laban did not regard him as favorably as he did before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Jacob, “Return to the land of your ancestors and to your kindred, and I will be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob sent and called Rachel and Leah into the field where his flock was
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to them, “I see that your father does not regard me as favorably as he did before. But the God of my father has been with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that I have served your father with all my strength,
speaker: Narrator

text: yet your father has cheated me and changed my wages ten times, but God did not permit him to harm me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he said, ‘The speckled shall be your wages,’ then all the flock bore speckled, and if he said, ‘The striped shall be your wages,’ then all the flock bore striped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus God has taken away the livestock of your father and given them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “During the mating of the flock I once had a dream in which I looked up and saw that the male goats that leaped upon the flock were striped, speckled, and mottled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of God said to me in the dream, ‘Jacob,’ and I said, ‘Here I am!’
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, ‘Look up and see that all the goats that leap on the flock are striped, speckled, and mottled, for I have seen all that Laban is doing to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar and made a vow to me. Now leave this land at once and return to the land of your birth.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rachel and Leah answered him, “Is there any portion or inheritance left to us in our father’s house?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are we not regarded by him as foreigners? For he has sold us, and he has been using up the money given for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the property that God has taken away from our father belongs to us and to our children; now then, do whatever God has said to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob arose and set his children and his wives on camels,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he drove away all his livestock, all the property that he had gained, the livestock in his possession that he had acquired in Paddan-aram, to go to his father Isaac in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Laban had gone to shear his sheep, and Rachel stole her father’s household gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob deceived Laban the Aramean, in that he did not tell him that he intended to flee.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he fled with all that he had; starting out he crossed the Euphrates and set his face toward the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day Laban was told that Jacob had fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took his kinsfolk with him and pursued him for seven days until he caught up with him in the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God came to Laban the Aramean in a dream by night and said to him, “Take heed that you say not a word to Jacob, either good or bad.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban overtook Jacob. Now Jacob had pitched his tent in the hill country, and Laban with his kinsfolk camped in the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said to Jacob, “What have you done? You have deceived me and carried away my daughters like captives of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you flee secretly and deceive me and not tell me? I would have sent you away with mirth and songs, with tambourine and lyre.
speaker: Narrator

text: And why did you not permit me to kiss my sons and my daughters farewell? What you have done is foolish.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is in my power to do you harm, but the God of your father spoke to me last night, saying, ‘Take heed that you speak to Jacob neither good nor bad.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though you had to go because you longed greatly for your father’s house, why did you steal my gods?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob answered Laban, “Because I was afraid, for I thought that you would take your daughters from me by force.
speaker: Narrator

text: But anyone with whom you find your gods shall not live. In the presence of our kinsfolk, point out what I have that is yours, and take it.” Now Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen the gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Laban went into Jacob’s tent and into Leah’s tent and into the tent of the two maids, but he did not find them. And he went out of Leah’s tent and entered Rachel’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Rachel had taken the household gods and put them in the camel’s saddle and sat on them. Laban felt all about in the tent but did not find them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she said to her father, “Let not my lord be angry that I cannot rise before you, for the way of women is upon me.” So he searched but did not find the household gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob became angry and upbraided Laban. Jacob said to Laban, “What is my offense? What is my sin, that you have hotly pursued me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Although you have felt about through all my goods, what have you found of all your household goods? Set it here before my kinsfolk and your kinsfolk, so that they may decide between us two.
speaker: Narrator

text: These twenty years I have been with you; your ewes and your female goats have not miscarried, and I have not eaten the rams of your flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: That which was torn by wild beasts I did not bring to you; I bore the loss of it myself; of my hand you required it, whether stolen by day or stolen by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was like this with me: by day the heat consumed me and the cold by night, and my sleep fled from my eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: These twenty years I have been in your house; I served you fourteen years for your two daughters and six years for your flock, and you have changed my wages ten times.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the God of my father, the God of Abraham and the Fear of Isaac, had not been on my side, surely now you would have sent me away empty-handed. God saw my affliction and the labor of my hands and rebuked you last night.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban answered and said to Jacob, “The daughters are my daughters, the children are my children, the flocks are my flocks, and all that you see is mine. But what can I do today about these daughters of mine or about their children whom they have borne?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, let us make a covenant, you and I, and let it be a witness between you and me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob took a stone and set it up as a pillar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob said to his kinsfolk, “Gather stones,” and they took stones and made a heap, and they ate there by the heap.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban called it Jegar-sahadutha, but Jacob called it Galeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “This heap is a witness between you and me today.” Therefore he called it Galeed
speaker: Narrator

text: and the pillar Mizpah, for he said, “The Lord watch between you and me, when we are absent one from the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you ill-treat my daughters or if you take wives in addition to my daughters, though no one else is with us, remember that God is witness between you and me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban said to Jacob, “See this heap and see the pillar, which I have set between you and me.
speaker: Narrator

text: This heap is a witness, and the pillar is a witness, that I will not pass beyond this heap to you, and you will not pass beyond this heap and this pillar to me, for harm.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the God of Abraham and the God of Nahor judge between us.” So Jacob swore by the Fear of his father Isaac,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Jacob offered a sacrifice on the height and called his kinsfolk to eat bread, and they ate bread and tarried all night in the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early in the morning Laban rose up and kissed his grandchildren and his daughters and blessed them; then he departed and returned home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob went on his way, and the angels of God met him;
speaker: Narrator

text: when Jacob saw them he said, “This is God’s camp!” So he called that place Mahanaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob sent messengers before him to his brother Esau in the land of Seir, the country of Edom,
speaker: Narrator

text: instructing them, “Thus you shall say to my lord Esau: Thus says your servant Jacob, ‘I have lived with Laban as an alien and stayed until now,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I have oxen, donkeys, flocks, male and female slaves, and I have sent to tell my lord, in order that I may find favor in your sight.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The messengers returned to Jacob, saying, “We came to your brother Esau, and he is coming to meet you, and four hundred men are with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob was greatly afraid and distressed, and he divided the people who were with him and the flocks and herds and camels into two companies,
speaker: Narrator

text: thinking, “If Esau comes to the one company and destroys it, then the company that is left will escape.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob said, “O God of my father Abraham and God of my father Isaac, O Lord who said to me, ‘Return to your country and to your kindred, and I will do you good,’
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not worthy of the least of all the steadfast love and all the faithfulness that you have shown to your servant, for with only my staff I crossed this Jordan, and now I have become two companies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Deliver me, please, from the hand of my brother, from the hand of Esau, for I am afraid of him; he may come and kill us all, the mothers with the children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet you have said, ‘I will surely do you good and make your offspring as the sand of the sea, which cannot be counted because of their number.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he spent that night there, and from what he had with him he took a present for his brother Esau,
speaker: Narrator

text: two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,
speaker: Narrator

text: thirty milch camels and their colts, forty cows and ten bulls, twenty female donkeys and ten male donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: These he delivered into the hand of his servants, every drove by itself, and said to his servants, “Pass on ahead of me, and put a space between drove and drove.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He instructed the one in the lead, “When Esau my brother meets you and asks you, ‘To whom do you belong? Where are you going? And whose are these ahead of you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: then you shall say, ‘They belong to your servant Jacob; they are a present sent to my lord Esau, and moreover he is behind us.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: He likewise instructed the second and the third and all who followed the droves, “You shall say the same thing to Esau when you meet him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you shall say, ‘Moreover your servant Jacob is behind us.’ ” For he thought, “I may appease him with the present that goes ahead of me, and afterwards I shall see his face; perhaps he will accept me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the present passed on ahead of him, and he himself spent that night in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same night he got up and took his two wives, his two maids, and his eleven children and crossed the ford of the Jabbok.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took them and sent them across the stream, and likewise everything that he had.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob was left alone, and a man wrestled with him until daybreak.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man saw that he did not prevail against Jacob, he struck him on the hip socket, and Jacob’s hip was put out of joint as he wrestled with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Let me go, for the day is breaking.” But Jacob said, “I will not let you go, unless you bless me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to him, “What is your name?” And he said, “Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man said, “You shall no longer be called Jacob, but Israel, for you have striven with God and with humans and have prevailed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob asked him, “Please tell me your name.” But he said, “Why is it that you ask my name?” And there he blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob called the place Peniel, saying, “For I have seen God face to face, yet my life is preserved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sun rose upon him as he passed Penuel, limping because of his hip.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore to this day the Israelites do not eat the thigh muscle that is on the hip socket, because he struck Jacob on the hip socket at the thigh muscle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jacob looked up and saw Esau coming, and four hundred men with him. So he divided the children among Leah and Rachel and the two maids.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the maids with their children in front, then Leah with her children, and Rachel and Joseph last of all.
speaker: Narrator

text: He himself went on ahead of them, bowing himself to the ground seven times, until he came near his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Esau ran to meet him and embraced him and fell on his neck and kissed him, and they wept.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Esau looked up and saw the women and children, he said, “Who are these with you?” Jacob said, “The children whom God has graciously given your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the maids drew near, they and their children, and bowed down;
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah likewise and her children drew near and bowed down; and finally Joseph and Rachel drew near, and they bowed down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said, “What do you mean by all this company that I met?” Jacob answered, “To find favor with my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Esau said, “I have enough, my brother; keep what you have for yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said, “No, please; if I find favor with you, then accept my present from my hand, for truly to see your face is like seeing the face of God, since you have received me with such favor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please accept my gift that is brought to you, because God has dealt graciously with me and because I have everything I want.” So he urged him, and he took it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau said, “Let us journey on our way, and I will go alongside you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob said to him, “My lord knows that the children are frail and that the flocks and herds, which are nursing, are a care to me, and if they are overdriven for one day, all the flocks will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let my lord pass on ahead of his servant, and I will lead on slowly, according to the pace of the cattle that are before me and according to the pace of the children, until I come to my lord in Seir.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau said, “Let me leave with you some of the people who are with me.” But he said, “Why should my lord be so kind to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau returned that day on his way to Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob journeyed to Succoth and built himself a house and made booths for his cattle; therefore the place is called Succoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob came safely to the city of Shechem, which is in the land of Canaan, on his way from Paddan-aram, and he camped before the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from the sons of Hamor, Shechem’s father, he bought for one hundred pieces of money the plot of land on which he had pitched his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: There he erected an altar and called it El-Elohe-Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Dinah the daughter of Leah, whom she had borne to Jacob, went out to visit the daughters of the region.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Shechem son of Hamor the Hivite, prince of the region, saw her, he seized her and lay with her by force.
speaker: Narrator

text: And his soul was drawn to Dinah daughter of Jacob; he loved the young woman and spoke tenderly to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Shechem spoke to his father Hamor, saying, “Get me this girl to be my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jacob heard that Shechem had defiled his daughter Dinah, but his sons were with his cattle in the field, so Jacob held his peace until they came.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hamor the father of Shechem went out to Jacob to speak with him,
speaker: Narrator

text: just as the sons of Jacob came in from the field. When they heard of it, the men were indignant and very angry, because he had committed an outrage in Israel by lying with Jacob’s daughter, for such a thing ought not to be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Hamor spoke with them, saying, “The heart of my son Shechem longs for your daughter; please give her to him in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make marriages with us; give your daughters to us, and take our daughters for yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall live with us, and the land shall be open to you; live and trade in it and get property in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shechem also said to her father and to her brothers, “Let me find favor with you, and whatever you say to me I will give.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put the marriage present and gift as high as you like, and I will give whatever you ask me; only give me the young woman to be my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jacob answered Shechem and his father Hamor deceitfully because he had defiled their sister Dinah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to them, “We cannot do this thing, to give our sister to one who is uncircumcised, for that would be a disgrace to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only on this condition will we consent to you: that you will become as we are and every male among you be circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we will give our daughters to you, and we will take your daughters for ourselves, and we will live among you and become one people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you will not listen to us and be circumcised, then we will take our daughter and be gone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Their words pleased Hamor and Hamor’s son Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the young man did not delay to do the thing because he was delighted with Jacob’s daughter. Now he was the most honored of all his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hamor and his son Shechem came to the gate of their city and spoke to the men of their city, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “These people are friendly with us; let them live in the land and trade in it, for the land is large enough for them; let us take their daughters in marriage, and let us give them our daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only on this condition will they agree to live among us, to become one people: that every male among us be circumcised as they are circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Will not their livestock, their property, and all their animals be ours? Only let us agree with them, and they will live among us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And all who went out of the city gate heeded Hamor and his son Shechem, and every male was circumcised, all who went out of the gate of his city.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day, when they were still in pain, two of the sons of Jacob, Simeon and Levi, Dinah’s brothers, took their swords and came against the city unawares and killed all the males.
speaker: Narrator

text: They killed Hamor and his son Shechem with the sword and took Dinah out of Shechem’s house and went away.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the other sons of Jacob came upon the slain and plundered the city because their sister had been defiled.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took their flocks and their herds, their donkeys, and whatever was in the city and in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: All their wealth, all their little ones and their wives, all that was in the houses, they captured and made their prey.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, “You have brought trouble on me by making me odious to the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites and the Perizzites; my numbers are few, and if they gather themselves against me and attack me, I shall be destroyed, both I and my household.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they said, “Should our sister be treated like a prostitute?”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to Jacob, “Arise, go up to Bethel, and settle there. Make an altar there to the God who appeared to you when you fled from your brother Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob said to his household and to all who were with him, “Put away the foreign gods that are among you, and purify yourselves, and change your clothes;
speaker: Narrator

text: then come, let us go up to Bethel, that I may make an altar there to the God who answered me in the day of my distress and has been with me wherever I have gone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they gave to Jacob all the foreign gods that they had and the rings that were in their ears, and Jacob hid them under the oak that was near Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they journeyed, a terror from God fell upon the cities all around them, so that no one pursued them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob came to Luz, that is, Bethel, which is in the land of Canaan, he and all the people who were with him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and there he built an altar and called the place El-bethel, because it was there that God had revealed himself to him when he fled from his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Deborah, Rebekah’s nurse, died, and she was buried under an oak below Bethel. So it was called Allon-bacuth.
speaker: Narrator

text: God appeared to Jacob again when he came from Paddan-aram, and he blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to him, “Your name is Jacob; no longer shall you be called Jacob, but Israel shall be your name.” So he was called Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to him, “I am God Almighty: be fruitful and multiply; a nation and a company of nations shall come from you, and kings shall spring from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land that I gave to Abraham and Isaac I will give to you, and I will give the land to your offspring after you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God went up from him at the place where he had spoken with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob set up a pillar in the place where he had spoken with him, a pillar of stone, and he poured out a drink offering on it and poured oil on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob called the place where God had spoken with him Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they journeyed from Bethel, and when they were still some distance from Ephrath, Rachel was in childbirth, and she had hard labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she was in her hard labor, the midwife said to her, “Do not be afraid, for now you have another son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As her soul was departing, for she was dying, she named him Ben-oni, but his father called him Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Rachel died, and she was buried on the way to Ephrath, that is, Bethlehem,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Jacob set up a pillar at her grave; it is the pillar of Rachel’s tomb, which is there to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel journeyed on and pitched his tent beyond the tower of Eder.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While Israel lived in that land, Reuben went and lay with Bilhah his father’s concubine, and Israel heard of it.
Now the sons of Jacob were twelve.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Leah: Reuben (Jacob’s firstborn), Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Rachel: Joseph and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Bilhah, Rachel’s maid: Dan and Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Zilpah, Leah’s maid: Gad and Asher. These were the sons of Jacob who were born to him in Paddan-aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob came to his father Isaac at Mamre, or Kiriath-arba, that is, Hebron, where Abraham and Isaac had resided as aliens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the days of Isaac were one hundred eighty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaac breathed his last; he died and was gathered to his people, old and full of days, and his sons Esau and Jacob buried him.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the descendants of Esau, that is, Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau took his wives from the Canaanites: Adah daughter of Elon the Hittite, Oholibamah daughter of Anah son of Zibeon the Hivite,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Basemath, Ishmael’s daughter, sister of Nebaioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adah bore Eliphaz to Esau; Basemath bore Reuel;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Oholibamah bore Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These are the sons of Esau who were born to him in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau took his wives, his sons, his daughters, and all the members of his household, his cattle, all his livestock, and all the property he had acquired in the land of Canaan, and he moved to a land some distance from his brother Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: For their possessions were too great for them to live together; the land where they were staying could not support them because of their livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau settled in the hill country of Seir; Esau is Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the descendants of Esau, ancestor of the Edomites, in the hill country of Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of Esau’s sons: Eliphaz, the son of Adah the wife of Esau; Reuel, the son of Esau’s wife Basemath.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Timna was a concubine of Eliphaz, Esau’s son; she bore Amalek to Eliphaz. These were the sons of Adah, Esau’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the sons of Basemath, Esau’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah, daughter of Anah son of Zibeon; she bore to Esau Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the clans of the sons of Esau. The sons of Eliphaz the firstborn of Esau: the clans Teman, Omar, Zepho, Kenaz,
speaker: Narrator

text: Korah, Gatam, and Amalek; these are the clans of Eliphaz in the land of Edom; they are the sons of Adah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Esau’s son Reuel: the clans Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah; these are the clans of Reuel in the land of Edom; they are the sons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah: the clans Jeush, Jalam, and Korah; these are the clans born of Esau’s wife Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Esau, that is, Edom, and these are their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Seir the Horite, the inhabitants of the land: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan; these are the clans of the Horites, the sons of Seir in the land of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Lotan were Hori and Heman, and Lotan’s sister was Timna.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Shobal: Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah; he is the Anah who found the springs in the wilderness as he pastured the donkeys of his father Zibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the children of Anah: Dishon and Oholibamah daughter of Anah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Dishon: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Ezer: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the clans of the Horites: the clans Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan; these are the clans of the Horites, clan by clan in the land of Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bela son of Beor reigned in Edom, the name of his city being Dinhabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bela died, and Jobab son of Zerah of Bozrah succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jobab died, and Husham of the land of the Temanites succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Husham died, and Hadad son of Bedad, who defeated Midian in the country of Moab, succeeded him as king, the name of his city being Avith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadad died, and Samlah of Masrekah succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samlah died, and Shaul of Rehoboth on the Euphrates succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaul died, and Baal-hanan son of Achbor succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Baal-hanan son of Achbor died, and Hadar succeeded him as king, the name of his city being Pau; his wife’s name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, daughter of Me-zahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the clans of Esau, according to their families and their localities by their names: the clans Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,
speaker: Narrator

text: Magdiel, and Iram; these are the clans of Edom, that is, Esau, the father of Edom, according to their settlements in the land that they held.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob settled in the land where his father had lived as an alien, the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the descendants of Jacob.
Joseph, being seventeen years old, was shepherding the flock with his brothers; he was a helper to the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, his father’s wives, and Joseph brought a bad report of them to their father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Israel loved Joseph more than any other of his children because he was the son of his old age, and he made him an ornamented robe.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when his brothers saw that their father loved him more than all his brothers, they hated him and could not speak peaceably to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once Joseph had a dream, and when he told it to his brothers, they hated him even more.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Listen to this dream that I dreamed.
speaker: Narrator

text: There we were, binding sheaves in the field. Suddenly my sheaf rose and stood upright; then your sheaves gathered around it and bowed down to my sheaf.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His brothers said to him, “Are you indeed to reign over us? Are you indeed to have dominion over us?” So they hated him even more because of his dreams and his words.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had another dream and told it to his brothers, saying, “Look, I have had another dream: the sun, the moon, and eleven stars were bowing down to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when he told it to his father and to his brothers, his father rebuked him and said to him, “What kind of dream is this that you have had? Shall we indeed come, I and your mother and your brothers, and bow to the ground before you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So his brothers were jealous of him, but his father kept the matter in mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now his brothers went to pasture their father’s flock near Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Israel said to Joseph, “Are not your brothers pasturing the flock at Shechem? Come, I will send you to them.” He answered, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he said to him, “Go now, see if it is well with your brothers and with the flock, and bring word back to me.” So he sent him from the valley of Hebron.
He came to Shechem,
speaker: Narrator

text: and a man found him wandering in the fields; the man asked him, “What are you seeking?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am seeking my brothers,” he said; “tell me, please, where they are pasturing the flock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man said, “They have gone away, for I heard them say, ‘Let us go to Dothan.’ ” So Joseph went after his brothers and found them at Dothan.
speaker: Narrator

text: They saw him from a distance, and before he came near to them they conspired to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to one another, “Here comes this dreamer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, let us kill him and throw him into one of the pits; then we shall say that a wild animal has devoured him, and we shall see what will become of his dreams.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Reuben heard it, he delivered him out of their hands, saying, “Let us not take his life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben said to them, “Shed no blood; throw him into this pit here in the wilderness, but lay no hand on him”—that he might rescue him out of their hand and restore him to his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when Joseph came to his brothers, they stripped him of his robe, the ornamented robe that he wore,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they took him and threw him into a pit. The pit was empty; there was no water in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they sat down to eat, and looking up they saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead, with their camels carrying gum, balm, and resin, on their way to carry it down to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah said to his brothers, “What profit is it if we kill our brother and conceal his blood?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let us sell him to the Ishmaelites and not lay our hands on him, for he is our brother, our own flesh.” And his brothers agreed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When some Midianite traders passed by, they drew Joseph up, lifting him out of the pit, and sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver. And they took Joseph to Egypt.
